Question_1.Context: The study discusses the use of a Fabry-Perot resonator and a distributed Bragg reflector in PbS colloidal quantum dot solar cells.
Question_1.Question: What is the main purpose of combining a Fabry-Perot resonator and a distributed Bragg reflector in PbS CQD solar cells?
Question_1.C: Reduce the thickness of the CQD film
Question_1.Source: The FP resonance enhances light absorption near the resonant wavelength of the DBR without changing the CQD film thickness.

Question_2.Context: The study mentions the importance of the device structure in designing CQD solar cells.
Question_2.Question: Why is the optimization of the thicknesses of the dielectric and metal layers crucial in the device structure?
Question_2.A: To control the optical transparency only
Question_2.B: To control the electric conductivity only
Question_2.C: To control the FP resonance wavelength
Question_2.D: To control the charge carrier diffusion length
Question_2.Source: They control not only the optical transparency and electric conductivity of the transparent electrode but also the FP resonance wavelength.

Question_3.Context: The study discusses the impact of the FP resonance and DBRs on the photovoltaic performance of PbS CQD solar cells.
Question_3.Question: What effect does the DBR have on the reflectance of the bottom Ag layer in the FP device?
Question_3.D: Shifts the reflectance to a different wavelength
Question_3.Source: The DBR-A exhibits the most enhancement. The DBR-A increases the reflectivity of the bottom Ag layer at the wavelength of the second FP resonance peak.

Question_4.Context: The study explores the development of semi-transparent PbS CQD solar cells.
Question_4.Question: What is the main advantage of the FP-STC device compared to the STC device?
Question_4.C: Higher transmittance in the NIR region
Question_4.D: Lower IPCE in the NIR region
Question_4.Source: When the FP resonance is formed by adding the NIR reflecting DBR, IPCE at the resonant wavelength increases by 440%.

Question_5.Context: The study discusses the impact of the incident light angle on the device structure.
Question_5.Question: How does the FP resonance wavelength in the FP-STC device change with an increase in the incident light angle?
Question_5.Source: This is because the optical path length through the FP resonance structure changes. An increase in the incident angle leads to a longer effective optical path length, resulting in the blue shift of resonance wavelength.

Question_6.Context: The study discusses the photovoltaic performance of different device structures.
Question_6.Question: What effect does the DBR have on the photovoltaic performance of the DBR-FP device compared to the FP device?
Question_6.Source: The DBR-FP CQD solar cells show a significant PCE boost by increasing both JSC and FF.

Question_7.Context: The study discusses the importance of the FP resonance and DBRs in enhancing light absorption.
Question_7.Question: What is the primary reason for adding DBRs to the FP device?
Question_7.D: To reduce the thickness of the PbS layer
Question_7.Source: Owing to the tunable reflection spectrum of the DBRs, the FP resonance can be strongly coupled to a high reflectance region of the DBRs.

Question_8.Context: The study discusses the impact of the DBR on the reflectance of the bottom Ag layer.
Question_8.Question: What is the effect of the DBR-A design on the reflectance of the bottom Ag layer?
Question_8.D: Shifts the reflectance to a different wavelength
Question_8.Source: The DBR-A exhibits the most enhancement. The DBR-A increases the reflectivity of the bottom Ag layer at the wavelength of the second FP resonance peak.

Question_9.Context: The study explores the development of semi-transparent PbS CQD solar cells.
Question_9.Question: What is the main advantage of the FP-STC device compared to the STC device?
Question_9.C: Higher transmittance in the NIR region
Question_9.D: Lower IPCE in the NIR region
Question_9.Source: When the FP resonance is formed by adding the NIR reflecting DBR, IPCE at the resonant wavelength increases by 440%.

Question_10.Question: How does the FP resonance wavelength in the FP-STC device change with an increase in the incident light angle?
Question_10.Source: This is because the optical path length through the FP resonance structure changes. An increase in the incident angle leads to a longer effective optical path length, resulting in the blue shift of resonance wavelength.
